title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act is titled the "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015". The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include details on the state of the public debt, historical levels, current amount, composition, future projections, and Federal revenue levels. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to provide Congress with a detailed report on various aspects related to the public debt, including future debt drivers, debt limit increase implications, reduction measures if the limit is not raised, and the potential recommendation for a balanced budget amendment. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the President to outline proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, assess the impact of increasing the debt limit on government spending and the dollar's status, project the fiscal health of major entitlement programs, and disclose weekly plans if the debt reaches the statutory limit. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on all current reduction measures to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including the total dollar amount used and estimated remaining amount for each measure. The report must also include the date when all measures will be exhausted, leading to default, and any extraordinary measures planned to fund federal obligations. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on current reduction measures to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including total dollar amount used, estimated remaining amount for each measure, date when measures will be exhausted, and any planned extraordinary measures to fund federal obligations. Additionally, a progress report on implementing President's proposals must be submitted if a Secretary has appeared at least once pursuant to this section during any term of office for a particular President. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide public access to information on debt reports, detailed explanations, and progress reports for at least 6 months. The term 'reduction measures' is defined as actions taken to issue debt by the Federal Financing Bank to avoid defaulting on government obligations. The Secretary of the Treasury can take various measures to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including suspending investments in certain funds, selling assets before maturity, and other appropriate actions as determined by the Secretary. The House of Representatives passed a report on February 11, 2016, before reaching the debt limit. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
